description.text:
This is a simple holder and console to mount a Baiway TK15 "Coulometer" battery monitor to the handle bar of a bicycle or scooter. The holder includes the mounting bracket for the handle bar. Bracket is designed for 22mm diameter handelbar. Console is behind handle bar and right side of bracket.

Coulometer TK15 is this thing:
https://wholesaler.alibaba.com/product-detail/BW-TK15-48V-50A-battery-monitor_60701416156.html

I included SketchUp files if you need to adapt things.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Use ABS if possible to get the mounting bracket durable enough.

Turn all objects 180° upside down to print (base plate stands upright them).

You need to drill the horizontal hole in the bracket with 3mm and the vertical hole with 4mm to make it smooth.

Depending what screws you have to mount the "Coulometer" (self tapping 2,5 x 15 or so) drill the holes in the cover to pass them and drill the holes in the base plate 0,5mm thiner so they can tap. If nexessary drill also the holes in the "Coulometer"-frontplate.

In the cover widen the pass hole for the cable depending on how thick your cable is.

So you need:

  • 1 3x20 mm screw with 2 washers and stoping nut for the horizontal bracket hole
  • 1 4x30 mm screw with nut for the vertical bracket hole
  • 2 2.5x15 mm or similar screw to fix the "Coulometer" to the console

Coffee Tamper - 50mm Diameter

Hope you like it.

PS: Could use some support, I printed it without any (Specially for the handle). But it will depend on your printer performance.

Printed mine with 0,4 Nozzle at 0,20 Layer height, 3 perimeters, 5 top and bottom layers, 25% Infill

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,20

Infill:

25%

comments.text: Printed one out and here are my observations. This will work with blackdog high cap mags for cmmg, but wont work for m261 blackdog mags. The pin is to far back for those. Now to the pin. It is to small, and breaks easy. I printed mine with ABS and a .8 nozzle with 2 walls so thr pin was solid, but it is not supported. Maybe if it was more of an oblong pin or was connected to the back somehow it would be stronger. Other than that it fits the magazine fine.
comments.author: Xacex

comments.text: thanks for the input. I actually made the pin 1mm diameter larger than the original version. I can increase the diameter maybe another 1mm wider but I want to make sure there is clearance between the feed lips. I am using a 0.4 mm nozzle it the pin is plenty strong to force 27 bullets into the cmmg mag using PLA. I think 0.4mm with 3 walls would be stronger than 0.8 nozzle with 2 walls.

title: Vortex Solo 10x36 Monocular Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've had this Vortex Solo Monocular on my belt for over two years now. I made the initial cap for it from a rubber cap I had laying around that happen to fit. I don't know why it doesn't come with a cap for the eye piece. It only came with an awkward tight fitting soft case that didn't easily let you use the belt clip. I work on an airport and like to see what's flying around or going on in far away areas. It also helps to read tail numbers to add to my collection. So since it pretty much goes everywhere with me and I am constantly outside working in a dusty industrial environment I want to protect that glass.

The cap is designed with slots that taper at the end to grip the nubs on the focus ring. The inner diameter of the cap is made to snug up to the rubber knurling on the focus ring to provide additional grip. With both of these features I can handle the scope once removed from my belt by the cap without it dropping it(though for the safety of the equipment I wouldn't recommend handling by the cap due to Murphy's law). The cap only requires a small amount of energy to pop off and just slips back on. The inner diameter is ~1.68 inches. If you happen to print one for your scope be sure to let me know how it works out.

title: Thermometer Clip for 13mm Fish Tank Thermometer

description.text:
A simple thermometer clip for most used 13mm fish tank thermometers. The usually provided suction cups tend to lose force when algae start to grow on the glass panes or when the rubber starts to stiffen.
Can be clipped to 3mm or 4mm glass panes. Maybe also thicker panes (5mm, 6mm) might be possible when bending the clip a bit.
2 versions available: one with flat edges and one with rounded ones.

author: spincrisis

description.text:
TL:DR
Print 4x of the rectangle feet for your chair, you may need to scale a bit.
Remove the included rubber feet, slip on your printed ones, enjoy.
**Note the included ones may be glued on better than mine were.
Some older Revs are in the Zip, and are NOT recommended under normal conditions.


So let’s start with a story.

Back early in 2017 I bought a pair of these:
https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B0727VDGCR/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

My friend had the original versions of them, but I didn't feel like spending $150 on a little chair.
So one day while browsing the interwebz, I saw these nice little ones that cost much less, so I bought them and life was great.
Now in Vancouver, we have some great fireworks every summer, and I was like “Awesome! Got chairs, they fit in my backpack, and I can take them on my motorcycle.” So I went down to the waterfront, staked out my spot, and enjoyed the show. BUT the chair kept sinking into the sand. At some point in the night during the readjustment, I somehow lost the included feet. I was kinda pissed, but like, we can fix that. 
Not only could I fix that, I could improve the design. As we kept sinking into the sand, I figured I could use the snow shoe method, and create a wider base, have less sink, and replace what I lost.
So here we are. After a few revisions, because the first one was a rush, and the second I couldn’t math. V3 was ok, but V4 is the most refined.

author: mussy

description.text:
The Las Vegas sun crumbled the 40 nut caps that came with our patio furniture set. My wife suggested as one of my first creations I print replacement nut caps. After verifying the fit I loaded up my build plate in Cura and let'er rip. I found that the cap fit varies from nut to nut. I could push a few of the caps on with my fingers but I needed to tap most on with a rubber mallet for a nice tight fit.

Nut sizes vary slightly from manufacturer to manufacturer. This nut cap is a bit loose for the 6mm nuts that came with my Anet A8. If these don't have the right fit for your needs simply make micro adjustments to your slicer's size scale percentage to get the right fit. Measure the nut. Measure the nut cap. Do the math and increase or decrease accordingly. Though I have not tried it, with the right scaling this nut cap would likely work for SAE English sizes, too

title: Star Trek Discovery DISCO T-Shirt kit

description.text:
KIT that can be used to reproduce the DISCO T-shirt as seen on Star Trek: Discovery.

The "DISCO" text is as close to the original as I could come, and the Star Trek symbol is molded after the original.

I printed the two files in regular PLA, 0.2mm height, and then ironed them on a T-Shirt with the iron at max settings and a sheet of non-stick cooking paper between the plastic and the iron. You need to be kinda careful because too little iron and the parts won't stick to the shirt and will curl in on themselves; but if you press too much or too long, you might end up smudging or deforming the prints (the "D" in the second design with the correct "C" did warp, as you can see from the picture).

Ultimately, it boils down to three factors:

1) Print a thin layer, 0.2 or 0.3mm, no raft, and peel it off the bed very carefully. Printing on painter's tape really helps!
2) Place all parts on a T-Shirt and place non-stick baking paper above the plastic. The iron should never, EVER touch plastic parts.
3) Heat the PLA with the iron so that it melts into the fabric, but not too much that it smears or deforms.

The only downside to this process is that PLA isn't very much flexible so, when it cools down, it's quite hard. If you do big designs, they might be uncomfortable to wear. Also, washing / re-ironing the shirt will certainly be a problem.

From what I've seen / researched, flexible filaments might be better suited for this kind of job; I'm waiting to receive some samples to try them.

Other than that, enjoy your DISCO t-shirt!

Rafts:

No

title: Threaded Hose Barb pipe fitting for Hot Tub heater

description.text:
I needed replacements for broken original pipe fittings that go into the Hot Tub heater. (240V6KW SSE-00-OH-OF 19400 0034 Watkins MFG Corp) Could not find anything that would fit. This was neither 3/4 nor 1 inch hose barb. So I decided to print this part. PLA cracked every time that I tried to install it. So then I switched to ABS. The ring right above the threads drips a little during print. I should probably change the design slightly so that it angles out. But I just wanted to get into my hot tub again, so I was in a bit of a rush. :) It occurs to me now that an adventurous printing person might try printing this upside down so that the flange edge would taper out. I didn't try this because I was worried about the part being top heavy and coming lose from the build plate.

I modified the original attempt and made it so it flanges back in to the barb. I had one snap off when I tried to fit a cold hose over it and put too much stress on it. My theory is that this will give it a little more strength. ( I would also recommend using teflon tape on the threads, even tho this is plastic. Carefully tighten and do not over-tighten.)

UPDATE - A friend recommended that I try printing the part in PETG. I did that and it was much stronger and much more resistant to cracking or breaking. I would recommend printing it with PETG. Oh, and definitely flip this thing upside down to print it. It comes out much cleaner and was not a problem.

The OpenSCAD drawing requires a couple of libraries. I made use of the Threads.scad and hollowCylinder.scad library. Both are found here at Thingiverse.

bolts, nuts, threaded rods - OpenSCAD library Threading.scad
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659079

OpenSCAD Hollow Cylinder
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2015451

title: Flite Test Inspired foam board cutter jig
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Flite test has helped open the hobby of model aircraft to the world. The hardest thing to get right is the bevel. Bixler can cut bevels blindfolded standing on his head with the razor held in his teeth....I am no where near as good as that man. I find that as my flying skills improve I am making fewer parts and repairs. With that my bevel skill drops and when it is time to make something new all my cuts are ugly. I decided to do something about it and have gone down a long road of testing and developing this tool. It has a flexible hinge area to help deal with the slight variance in foam thickness and also helps you grip the foam as you cut. It works great for single and double bevel. For single sheets you will need a scrap piece of foam to put underneath as the tool was spaced for double sheets. It comes in a left handed and right handed flavor and I recommended printing both because there are some areas where the finger grip will prevent you from finishing a cut. At that point you just grab the opposite tool and swap it in and you should be able to finish that last little bit. The blade can be laid flat on the surface of the tool and either gently pulled or with a slight sawing action to cut through the foam, just make sure your angle isn't to high otherwise you start to dig into the tool which will add up over time.
I have done four wings with this tool and quite a few control surfaces and have yet to burn through the paper. I hope this helps take the frustration out of beveling and make it a little easier. I am also hoping for some real world usage to see if there is anything else I should change or redesign to make this task easier. I've given some out to friends and haven't heard any complaints yet.

I've printed them in ABS and PLA and both seem fine. I'm at certain points a little more fond of the feeling and look of ABS over standard PLA but ABS also adds a little more flex to that joint making it a little easier to work with.

description.text:
Designed to work with this switch https://www.banggood.com/1pcs-10A-250V-3Pin-IEC320-C14-Inlet-Module-Plug-Fuse-With-Switch-Male-Power-Socket-p-1120059.html?

I made this with 2 parts in order to lie the PSU out of the way at the back of the machine and have easy access to the switch. Added benefit is that the fan blows away from the build plate

There is an extra 5mm hole at the top of the unit for the cable to the part cooling fan to ensure it is long enough to reach maximum print height. Power cable and permanent fan exit the box via a channel in the base

The stl file includes two extended corners to ensure warp free printing with ABS. These can be easily removed when the print is completed. Added a file without the extended corners which prints well in PLA

This design only really works if you intend to screw the unit to a base board

author: teikjoon

title: Anti-Theft Fake Stereo Cover - Single DIN
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have a flip out face Pioneer head unit, AVH-7800BT and I have an old 87 Ford Bronco with a single DIN setup with the AC controls on top and simply NOT a suitable place to install a single DIN motorized, flip out face.

Oh yeah, I also don't want anyone recognizing the unit and thinking it's a good idea to steal it ;) My truck doesn't look fancy but it has no rear roof and I always keep the windows down unless it's cold. Considering how easy it is to steal a deck from one of these older trucks, I figured I'd add in a real deterrent. Make it look like the old crappy (cool at the time) cassette
tape deck :D

It's just a cover but you can add an LCD sticker or even a real LCD and all the fancy stuff to make it more like a stereo. If you wanna go the extra mile, get an old cassette tape like I did, cut off 1/4 of it, and glue it so it looks like a real tape is sticking out :D

So there are two pieces.
The Shim is mostly for my truck and the space I need to keep the deck out in order for clearance. I still think this piece will be necessary but that depends on if you can slide your deck out permanently. I plan to attach a SMALL piece of velcro to the top. I say small because it's a flip out so I'd like the cover to come off really easy and fall to the floor if the face moves out while the cover is on.
This solved problem #1

The Cover is the fake radio cover. Again, "deck" it out! But plain will do well enough. So if you've got a good flush proper install and don't need the shim, you'll still need a small piece of velcro to make this work for you. Stick it on top of your bezel, and then the other side to a relative spot that'll line up. I shouldn't have to explain ;)
This solved problem #2

So now you've got your fake deck! Leave the windows down, and walk away with a bit more piece of mind!

author: entityunknown

description.text:
My biology class inspired me to design this when we learned about viruses. I've learned a lot about Onshape's FeatureScript while working on this (which was part of the goal), as well as practiced a bunch of trigonometry (which is good since I'm taking a calculus class right now).

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/21fe442c6fdbdcc9cb2b762c/v/cd375aa1a27586361611008f/e/aff030f8e2b8273743bfc213

It should allow copying the document to allow editing the parameters, but I can't really check without creating a new Onshape account.

I still have a few more parameter options I want to add, but this accomplishes what I originally set out to do.
This also uses Onshape user Leon Poot's "Non-Uniform Scaling in Direction" feature, which is really awesome.

author: blakebcg

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner
For a Bastion main ;)

Printer:

Anet A8

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

In the late 1700s Eli Whitney, the designer of the cotton gin, developed muskets with interchangeable parts to help the United States military. The manufacture of objects with interchangeable parts was soon a key factor in the industrial revolution. Mr. Whitney is perhaps a little anachronistic when brought alongside castle and siege warfare, but we can use the principles he championed to build a better piece of siege machinery. In this spirit, and on July 4th, America's Independence Day, I would like to share the Universal Catapult for Seej. (More information about Seej can be found here: http://www.zheng3.com/seej/ ). Some friends and I started to play Seej, using the basic set ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24013 ). Maybe it was our technique, maybe it was the rubber bands we had on hand, but we found the rubber-band-as-pivot to be woefully inaccurate and nearly unplayable. I set off to build a better catapult. After two rounds of revisions, I'm posting the v03 Universal Catapult design. This catapult has three main features going for it: Tension Keys - The tension keys pull the rubber bands instead of twisting them. This leads to fewer twisty knots and better linear tension. Adjustable Strike Plate - I only have the one strike plate for now, but in theory, you should be able to swap them out for plates of varying depth. This allows for more fine control of the angle of release. Modular Base - Everything sits atop a base with modular holes. If you would like to design a trebuchet, ballista, or even gatling gun or death-laser, then feel free to skip reinventing the base and use this one. See the base detail image for exact measurements. The OpenSCAD source files are also attached. For the blog post announcing this model, read http://netninja.com/2012/07/04/the-universal-catapult-for-seej/ For the blog post presenting the earlier revisions that led to this one, read http://netninja.com/2012/08/12/the-evolution-of-a-catapult/

Print the following pieces in these quantities:
  • â€¢ Base, x2, base.stl, white in the image
  • â€¢ Base Struts, x2, strut.stl, gray in the image
  • â€¢ Rubber-band tension keys, x2, key.stl, yellow in the image
  • â€¢ Sides, x2, side.stl, brown in the image
  • â€¢ Arm, x1, arm.stl green in the image
  • â€¢ Strike plate, x1, brace.stl, blue in the image
    • I used the Replicator defaults, but bumped up the number of shells to 2 on the arm and keys. Assemble the plastic parts as pictured. With heavy office rubber bands, I use two -- one from the catapult arm to the peg of each key. For longer, thiner rubber bands, I would suggest looping the rubber band from the peg of one key to the catapult arm and over to the peg of the other key. Once the rubber bands are in place, the keys can be turned to adjust tension. Pull the keys up slightly, turn, and re-seat to adjust the catapult strength.

comments.text: Since you were shooting (pun) for accuracy . . . why did you stick with rubber bands?  Why not springs or repelling magnets?  Rubber bands deteriorate gradually with use.  Springs as well, but much less.  Magnets . . . generally you wouldn't notice a changed in this century.  Just curious.
comments.author: sgreenwalt

comments.text: Given that this was designed to be a kid's toy (a different catapult design for the Seej game), I went with common household items — just like the original game. Not everyone has a spring with a specific length and tension coefficient, nor does everyone have neodymium magnets of a specific size and strength lying around in their junkdrawer at home.
comments.author: sgreenwalt

comments.text: dues it shoot
comments.author: c15

comments.text: Xerxes' observation is pretty much spot-on. Printed every part in PLA in one go, they all came out spectacular except for a tiny bit of warping in one of my base plates, although it has no effect on the model itself. Every part goes together fantastically, although the tensioner keys are a tad loose in their slots and sometimes forcefully eject when a projectile is launched. I just put a layer of blue tape around the circular peg that sits inside the base piece and they stay put now. Coins are thrown about straight, maybe a five or ten degree angle. Strike plate experimentation is in order. Oh, and one last thing - the slot is too small for an american penny. I just put a penny in, used a torch on it, then squished it into the slot. Works like a charm.
comments.author: grabercars

comments.text: This printed great! Snapped together solidly. Tension keys are very functional and easy to use. It shoots pretty much straight on, which is fine. I'll probably make the strike plate wider (towards the arm) so it will launch a little more vertically--and the modular design makes for easy switching of the strike plate. A longer arm would also be nice since the tension keys are close to either side of the arm, cramping the room to hold the arm down. Overall, though, a very nice design and I will be replacing my kids' arsenal with these.
comments.author: xerxes

comments.text:
I've found string works much much better than elastic bands with the original design - just wrap it between the keys a few times, then tighten (fiddly). I went from pennies going half a metre to
&
gt;5m :)

This is a model and OpenSCAD file for a mold used to make silicone SimpleSumo robot mini-sumo tires.

Case for the NanoPi Neo Plus2, with heatsink.

Can use either machine screws or self-tapping (3mm x 20mm or 4G x 3/4in) to assemble - the countersunk holes are 3mm dia and the holes to screw into are 2.5mm dia.

I bought some of these SAS caddies for my Lenovo SA-120 drive bay. Unfortunately, the side clips are very fragile and I had a few broken just pulling the drive caddies out of the box. I took some measurements and replicated the clips pretty well. I'll be honest, they don't stay in the caddy super well, but they were plenty well enough and I was able to use these instead.

For mine, I printed them using Cura's Ultra-fine quality setting (0.06mm layer height) on a Makergear M2 using Hatchbox black PLA, no infill, no supports. I also printed them ultra-slow at about 20-30mm/s. They came out well enough for me.

Hope they work well for you as well!

print_settings.Notes:: Getting the Clips to work was tricky. Might be a good idea to use supports for them, although I didn't. Also the button isn't perfect, it's a little loose in the spot. I might revise it further and anyone is welcome to revise it as well.

description.text:
A replacement reset button I made for a gamecube i'm repairing that had a missing one. Figured i'd upload the file as there's absolutely nothing online as far as replacement GCN parts. Let's change that.

V2 Released. Went through and re-modeled the entire thing using blender. Adjusted things until it's practically a 1:1 copy of the original. Be careful, for some reason the clips of this one have a tendency to break where the original models were quite a bit more flexy. Left the original file there just in case, but overall the 2nd version is better in every other respect.

It might be better to print it in a more flexible material OR if you can reduce the layer height around where the clips mount to the button.

Printer:

Dremel 3D20

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 micron

Infill:

default

Notes:

Getting the Clips to work was tricky. Might be a good idea to use supports for them, although I didn't. Also the button isn't perfect, it's a little loose in the spot. I might revise it further and anyone is welcome to revise it as well.

title: Anet A2 MGM15 linear rail Y axis mod

description.text:
This is a pack of all printed parts that are needed when upgrading Y axis on Anet A2/+ with MGN15 linear rail.
The belt tensioner part is a remix of Olev https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2157807 remixed to have a parallel belt when using mgn15 rail on Y axis, and to act as a mechanical stop for the rail carrier and with fatter sides for strength and to be able to use M5 T-nuts and screws for mounting on the aluminium 2040 profile. The only piece missing is the tensioner screw that remains exactly the same and you can get from Olevs design
.
The motor mount is recreated from original Anet acrylic mount remixed so to have a parallel belt for mgn15.

The infill for the tensioner parts is printed at 70% but I am almost sure 40% will be more than enough.
The infill for the Motor mount is printed at 100%, because unlike tensioner is an one side mount and it needs the strength for not flexing.

What I have found out is that eventhough linear rail and original acrylic carrier works OK with pla printing, when it comes to ABS and bed temperatures at about 100c because the carrier is mounted on a small rail carriage there is a bigger leverage, springs and heat flex the acrylic bed carrier and make it very difficult to level, and that leveling changes by heat continously. It is best to replace also bed carriage from acrylic to aluminum 3mm is perfect with no flex at all.

Printer:

Anet A2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

comments.text: Can you recommend the MGN rail update? Was the print quality improved much?
comments.author: Masochisti

comments.text: MGN rails Upgrade is the most important upgrade I've done to my Anet A2+. My wheel system was a disaster and I couldn't even level the bed right. The effect was like a really warped bed. MGN rails especially for Y axis solved this and the precision and smoothness is unmatched even comparing with higher quality printers as CR-10. BTW, you don't need an expensive rail, chineese rails even it is not as smooth as a way more expensive rails as e.g. HIWIN, are working great for 3d printer loads.
comments.author: Masochisti

comments.text: I have the same issue with my A2+ that I just built this last week.  I have a glass plate on my bed and I would level all four corners and then watched as the nozzle would travel down the the length of the Y-axis and notice the nozzle-to-bed distance would fluctuate.  This doesn't happen along the X-axis yet.  But I just ordered a pair of MGN rails to correct this.  The plastic wheels that came with my A2+ are not precision manufactured and don't run smoothly along the 2040 or 2020 rails.  This will take care of the leveling issue for me.  Only thing I have to deal with now is under extrusion.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Birthday cupcake toppers.

Update: 11/11/17 My daughter informed me that Supergirl and Superman logos are different. Superman yellow sections are solid- no blue on the inside. So here is the superman correction 'Yellow superman section'. I have not printed it. Might need slight filing/sanding to get to fit as supergirls are slights flexible and these won't be. Let me know if you need a slight adjustment. As always, please share you prints with pictures! And be the first to print this one!

SuperGirl logo printed in 3 parts and press-fit together. A drop of glue here and there might be good.
Brim needed for the yellow parts. The smallest one is hard to put in without dropping a few times. I put them in slightly then turn it over and pressed down to finish up

If needed, I used the Slic3r 'fix' for 'watertightness' (yellow parts needed it)

Brim also needed on the flash symbol for a better print. I didn't on this version, but will on the others.

description.text:
This is part of a project to create modular components for a portable handheld gaming system. This way novices can assemble any models they want to use and essentially "snap" them together to quickly prototype. This dpad box works with Sega Saturn Dpads, so far but I will add other versions to make swapping out styles easy. The Fusion 360 project file with all the sketches step by step instructions for creating the model (so that you can easily modify it). This is released under the public domain license so you can use it for reference, modify, or incorporate it into your project and sell it. There are three variants of the top; 1 with no lip, 1 with 2mm lip, and 1 with a 3mm lip.

Fusion 360 project file:
http://a360.co/2ixUNP9

Features: The box is designed to be swapped out with different dpad styles. I haven't yet designed the other case styles (Nintendo cross style, PS separate buttons) but I'd love any help in that.

It uses
M2 screws that are 8mm long

Adafruit's soft tactile switches
https://www.adafruit.com/product/3101

Replacement Saturn dpads I've tested it with this
https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/Replacement-for-Sega-Saturn-Controller-Arrow-Keys-Direction-Key-with-Cross-Buckle-for-SS-Controller/614632_32348389012.html

And also the dpads from the generic knock off controllers
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/for-PC-Sega-Saturn-System-Style-USB-Wired-Gamepad-Classic-Game-Controller-Gamepad-Joypad/32813855388.html?ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_3_10152_10065_10151_10344_10068_10345_10342_10343_10340_10341_10541_10084_10083_10307_10175_10060_10155_10154_10056_10055_10539_10537_10312_10536_10059_10313_10314_10534_10533_100031_10550_10103_10073_10551_10102_10552_10553_10554_10557_10142_10107-10550_10551_10553,searchweb201603_2,ppcSwitch_5&btsid=ac316935-3944-41b0-a0d9-af889630b43b&algo_expid=06c657fb-a594-4289-b0ff-e74b1080c7e7-0&algo_pvid=06c657fb-a594-4289-b0ff-e74b1080c7e7

Printer:

Creality CR-10s

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Be careful when removing supports from the underside of the top half.

Using a flying extruder like this one can shorten your retracts from 5-7mm down to about 2mm, because it will shorten your Bowden tube's length from ~450mm (for a 750mm tall printer) down to ~150mm. If you have a taller printer, this is an even bigger win.

This can work with a variety of extruders, but I'm using it with Shane's: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:245677
I've used the Shane's extruder on about 15 printers, and it has been very reliable. I like that it is easy to load, compact and that it doesn't use any unusual parts.
I use the variant which uses an M4 nut to secure the Teflon tubing and a Mk8 drive gear.

To build this, you'll need:

  • 2x M3x16 SHCS
  • 2x M3 nuts
  • 1x M3x10 SHCS
  • 4x M3 nylock nut
  • 3x 190mm long pieces of 3/8" OD, 1/4" ID rubber tubing. (These three pieces need to be slightly longer than half the length of the horizontal extrusions in a Delta printer.)
  • 1x KeyBak (heavy duty): https://www.amazon.com/KEY-BAK-Retractable-Stainless-Polycarbonate-Oversized/dp/B0088MQ9JS
  • 10x small zip ties

I am using this Flying Extruder in my Kumu-3D printer design: http://www.kumu-3d.com

Here are the steps to assemble the flying extruder suspender:

  • Use an M3x10 SHCS and an M3 nylock nut to attach the "wye" to the top of the motor suspender.
  • Slip one end of each of the three pieces of rubber tubing onto the three arms of the "wye", and use a small zip tie to secure each one.
  • Have an M3x35 SHCS (or something similar) go through each carriage, and extend toward the center of the printer. Slide each of the small printed tubes (which I call tubing adaptors) onto the ends of the M3x35's, and then use an M3 nylock nut to keep them from sliding off.
  • Slide the remaining free ends of the rubber tubing onto the tubing adaptors and use a small zip tie to secure each one.
  • Measure and shorten your Bowden tube. On my printers it is about 150mm, down from about 450mm. This reduced the retraction settings by a factor of 3x! Also, you can probably set your retraction acceleration to a large value -- I'm using 3000mm/s^2, and the retraction speed is 200mm/s.
  • On my printers I suspend the spool at the top, and I also have a piece of aluminum L-channel near the front, going between the top X-Z and Y-Z horizontal extrusions. I used two zip ties to attach the Key-Bak to this piece of aluminum L-channel, and an additional zip tie to act as a loose filament guide.
  • On the Key-Bak, I removed the split ring, and replaced it with a small zip tie. I used a little bit of fishing string looped around the three arms of the "wye", and have the zip tie running through these loops. This is how the Key-Bak pulls up on the "wye" to counter the extruder's weight.

comments.author: hlombard

comments.text:
The Key-Bak counters the weight of the extruder motor.
It will still work without it, however on my printers, when they finish printing, they'd home to the top, and because of the extruder motor's weight promptly settle down with the still-hot hotend on the freshly printed piece.

remixed_from.title: Monoprice MP Select Mini (MPSM) Tool Bracket/Holder

title: Monoprice MP Select Mini (MPSM) Tool Bracket/Holder - Remixed Holders

description.text:
This is NOT a complete tool bracket/holder!
See: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1688459 by eburgess4,

The original is a brilliant design. I'm just adding a few tweaked components.

I found even the "large" gluestick holder didn't fit the standard Elmer's 40g (1.41oz) gluesticks I use. So I've made one even BIGGER! 30mm inside diameter. After printing I felt it was likely to break over time so I beefed up the vertical support and added a bottom support to prevent the holder flexing backwards. But I've left the first version without the support in case someone needs it to clear something else on their printer.

I also found that the original tool holders don't fit tightly enough in the rails. So I've added 0.25mm top and bottom to make a tighter fit. This way if it's a bit too tight, at least it can be filed down for a perfect fit.

For anyone with loose fitting other tool holder components, rather than reprint - I'm adding a little stopper block (I've called it the LockBit) you can use to trap the loose fitting holders in place on the rail.

Tip: Don't forget to enable support (for the rail adapter on the gluestick holder)

Printed in PLA. Remixing in TinkerCAD because it's fast for simple tweaks like these.

title: Micro Switch Box and Cover for Articulating Lamp

description.text:
UPDATE: 12-25-17 (Merry Christmas!)
Micro Switch Box 2.3 Rocker & Micro Switch Box 2.3 Toggle: Added another larger hole at the bottom of the switch box The bottom cover holds in the wiring, this makes it much easier to solder the wires to the switch and then snap in the switch after soldering (At least for the rocker switch).

This is a Switch Box for the Articulated Lamp https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2505394, it snaps into the lamp arms from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2551878.
One box is for the Mini Rocker switch and the other box is for a mini toggle switch.

Mini Rocker example: http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItemVersion&item=401356090981&view=all&tid=665956224027,
Mini Toggle Example: https://www.ebay.com/itm/10-pcs-2-Pin-SPDT-ON-OFF-2-Position-250VAC-Mini-Toggle-Switches-MTS-101-US-Stock/361899399753?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2, 0.3

Infill:

support everywhere, 15%

Notes:

Printed on end seem to get the best results. Cover Snap fits into place. Box is small and tight, a little difficult soldering the wiring, but manageable. (Not with the new 2.3 version) I used Inland PLA 1.75mm, 205Deg C 0.4mm Extruder and 60Deg C heat bed. 65% Speed.
12-25-17, I finally went ahead and added extra opening for changing where the wires come in to the box, where only the lid holds the wires in place, it makes it easier to solder then install the switch.
Also when you wire the switch, only solder the load side (hot wire) to the switch. The neutral wire just connects to itself.
I made a ton of these lamps for Christmas gifts, you can go to dollar tree and get 2 wire six foot extension cords for $1, it has the plug end and I just cut off the receptacle end and then solder to the switch and lamp holder.

FreeCad

Used FreeCad software, Yes it's free, taking me a while to get the hang of it but I'm getting better. I use Catia V5 at work. This software is somewhat similar, but is missing some very nice features that Catia has. But it's free and I can't complain.

comments.text:
The nice thing about learning to design, is that if you don't see a lot of other peoples work that interests you, or the things you are interested in haven't been made yet you can be the one to bring those things to life. I've got a few obscure props I will be releasing on here in the next week or so, which are only brought to life because I wanted to design them, and that feels wonderful.

author: Mosin_Nagant

description.text:
Hex-Ominos (Designed and copyright owner of the main picture Cameron Browne)
The game uses a set of 55 Hexagonal dominoes, with numbers ranging from 0 to 9 at each corner. Shuffling is the same as with regular dominoes: turn then face-down and mix them up with your hands. Players then draw tiles, depending on how many are playing:
2 players draw 9 tiles each 3 or 4 players draw 7 tiles each
5 or 6 players draw 6 tiles each

The remainder of the tiles make up the "well", and are held in or reserve to be drawn upon at need. The player with the highest double places the first tile. The player receives the total number of points on the tile, plus a bonus of 10. If no one hold a double, then the tile with the largest point total leads. If the tile is not a double, then no bonus is awarded.
Play proceeds to the left (clockwise). Each player adds a tile to an open edge of the layout, if he can.
If a player is unable to make a move, he must draw tiles from the well until he can make a move. If there are no tiles left, then the player must pass. Passing scores minus 10 points.
A hand ends either when a player plays all his tiles, or when a game is blocked. A game is blocked when no player is able to add another tile to the layout.
Bridge - When a tile is added that bridges two parts of a layout, matching one side of a tile and the top of a tile opposite it, the player scored the points on his tile, plus a 40-point bonus.

comments.text: Please give proper credit to game designer and copyright owner of the main picture Cameron Browne.

Update 11/8: At it again with the hinges. Really digging them now. Seem applicable to other folding-box projects. Hmmm. Travel Go, anyone?

This is a lid for a baby food jar that can be used to make a fruit fly trap. I put a splash of apple cider vinegar into the jar, then snap/screwed this lid on (I measured it to be a tight fit). It happens to be in a format the customizer won't choke on, so go ahead and play with it. The values that worked for me are already loaded as defaults.

We had some apples that sat on the counter too long. Sure enough, fruit flies. And it's been a week now of these damn things. I glanced at the options to download/print a trap and I just got bored. Didn't seem like any less work to fiddle with someone else's design for such a simple part. And hell, I've been feeling depressive, so maybe an easy little project would cheer me up.

description.text:
iPhone 5 Otterbox Defender Series Laser Pointer Lens Holder for Macro Photography
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/iphone-5-otterbox-defender-series-laser-pointer-lens-holder-for-macro-photography--2

Update: 11/11
Re-work on retainer assembly to allow for more margin for error/less precise printing
Bolt increased to M8
Fattened out retainer clips
Extended Key Post (probably can get away with not reprinting this)

Will work on rotating parts to be print ready in next update

Design:
This is a long standing project of mine. The goal was to design a fully adjustable 3d printed spool/reel holder that can free-wheel. The result of my efforts is this.
The spool holder supports hole diameters between 51mm and 88mm.

The only additional hardware required is 8 small screws to mount the rail guides to the uprights. In future revisions I plan on reworking the adjustment system (think document feeder paper adjustment). For now, it is functional and rigid, but a little janky to adjust at the moment.

At the core of the project is emmett's Gear Bearings https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451 (give him some love). These make it possible for the spool to spin smoothly without needing to source bearings in small batches or any of that nonsense (no ebay).

Printing:
With the exception of the adjustable spool screw, everything can be printed without supports as long as you orient it correctly on the build plate. For the large spool screw, use supports for the lower bearing recess.

Tolerances - The tolerances are tight in the design, expect to do a little sanding (not much) on the parts that interact.
Gear Bearings:
I included STL files for gear bearing with fairly forgiving tolerances. If you have trouble with bound gear bearings, you may need to roll your own. The important dimensions for them are:
Outer Diameter: 39mm
Keyway Width: 6.5mm
Depth:10mm

Included is the CAD file for anyone who wants to hack away.

I designed this through repeated iteration. Getting the spline cup right was hard; I think I printed nearly 20 of them (at one point I had my printer on double speed and I was printing at 0.2 layer height).

Designed similar to original Ursa bear body. Will require a longer front body mount which is included. the rear body mount uses the same mount as the original Ursa bear body.
you will need 2 more 3mmX10 Screws for this body as the rollbar uses 4 bolts.

.2 Layer Height.

About 50 grams heavier then the original Ursa Bear body, this new body is wider, longer, and taller then original.

Parts list:
King URSA Center Body Piece (Cab center of body)
King URSA Front Body Mount (new longer front body mount for King Ursa, use original rear body mount)
King URSA Front body piece ( front/nose of body) insert a 100% layer at 115
King URSA Optional Grill Insert Piece 1 (to help with painting the Black outs for the hood ducts)
King URSA Optional Grill Insert Piece 2 (to help with painting the Black outs for the hood ducts)
King URSA Optional Grill Insert Piece 3 (to help with painting the Black outs for the hood ducts)
King URSA Rear Body Piece (rear body bed of truck, insert a 100% fill layer at 160)
King URSA Rear Window (glue to Cab, makes the rear window of the cab)
King URSA Roll Bar (body roll bar)

The Optional Grill inserts go into the hood. Glue them in place, they are meant to be tight but you may need to sand them to fit.

2% infill 1 perimeter for body. Rollbar 25% infill. Designed to print as orientated.

title: Adafruit HTU21D-F Temperature & Humidity Sensor Mounting Case

description.text:
A nice snap kit for packaging Adafruit HTU21D-F Temperature & Humidity Sensor breakout boards into a mountable casing. Comes in two prints which have a latch on the bottom to secure them together.

Vents in front of the sensor should allow for air to pass and not affect readings.

Top mount can be screwed into any frame with a variety of screw sizes.

Breakout pins (e.g. 0.1 inch) fit nicely in the design and there's room for the wire extrusion out the back of the breakout board for soldered connections.

Score board / score tracker with 8x8 grid. The pins fit inside the board holes but can also be stacked on top of each other. The board was originally created for Sushi Go. It is is less than 9cm wide and only a few mm tall, allowing it to fit inside the game box.

Due to the small size and making them stackable, the pins are a bit hard to manipulate. When space is not at a premium you might want to use something bigger, e.g. use colored M&Ms as score markers on this board.

Printed on a Sindoh DP200 set to 0.1mm layer height and 15% infill. To save some filament I'd recommend only using 2 solid layers on top and bottom for the board.

title: Insulation FoamBoard Enclosure Connector Clips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After several months of successful, summer printing, fall/winter is here and it is apparently too cold to print :( I needed something quick and cheap, so I decided to throw together an enclosure made of 1/2" insulation foamboard. It's not pretty and, unlike most of my projects, it's far from indestructible, but it is cheap - $8 per 4'x8' sheet - and using these clips, it's quick. It'll get me through the winter until a more permanent solution can be found.

This is designed so that the front piece of foam will slide up and down in the clips so that you can easily remove it to access your printer. I plan on cutting a hole in the front piece and gluing a piece of plexiglass over the hole on the outside as a window. I will probably also be adding LED mounting clips and a clip for an endoscope camera later on.

The DO_NOT_PRINT file should, obviously, not be printed. That's just for Thingiverse to use for a 3d rendering of the enclosure. You will need to print two of each bottom connector and one each of the four top connectors. For the edge connectors, print as many as you need for a sturdy enclosure. I'm only showing two per side in the rendering, but I think I will probably need three or four per side in reality.

I have printed the connectors and they fit perfectly on 1/2 Perma "R" Foamboard. You may want to glue the connectors in place with E6000 or Duco Cement. I am building this this weekend, so I will update if I run into any trouble. If these help you, please upload your own [I Made One] of your enclosure.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Turn the edge connectors on their sides and they will print with out supports. Orient the top and bottom pieces so that the largest flat area is flat against the bed. The bottom pieces do not need supports, but you will need supports turned on (supports everywhere) for the four top connectors.

The instruction below are taken from the included PDF in the download section and on our website. Please refer to the PDF instructions and drawings for details.

Glass Frame Arm Assembly Drawing No. 001083

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000984 Side Arm 1
2 000993 6mm Glass Left Side Clip 1
3 000998 6mm Glass Right Side Clip (Mirror 000993) 1
4 001010 Glass Upper Clip Clamp 1
5 001044 Glass Lower Clip Clamp 1
6 001062 Glass Frame Bracket 1
7 001074 ST2.2x6.5mm CROSS CSK TAP SCREW A2 3

Assemble the side arm paying particular attention to the orientation of the left and right glass side clips. Finished assembly should look as shown above.
To assemble the side arm place the 6mm Glass Left Side Clip (2) on the side arm locating it in the location holes. Slide the Glass Upper Clip Clamp (4) over both the arm (1) and the clip (2) until the front edge lines up with the edge of the clip (2). The screw pilot hole should be visible through the hole In the back of the clip. The clamp can be very tight, care must be taken while assembling. If too tight to fit use a fine file to make the clamp a looser fit. There is one fixing screw to secure the Glass Upper Clip Clamp (4). Do not overtighten
To assemble the lower end of the Glass Frame Arm Assembly follow the same procedure using the 6mm Glass Right Side Clip (3) but with the addition of the Glass Frame Bracket (6) positioned on the side arm. Use the Glass Lower Clip Clamp (5) to clamp to the side arm. Make sure the pilot holes are visible through the holes in the back of the Glass Lower Clip Clamp (5) and the edges of the clamp (5) and the 6mm Glass Right Side Clip (3) line up. There are two fixing screws (7) to secure the Glass Lower Clip Clamp (5). Do not overtighten.
Care must be taken to select the correct 6mm Glass Side Clips as they ca n be easily mixed up.
Once completed place to one side.

Glass Frame Assembly Drawing No. 000986

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000984 Side Arm 1
2 000985 Glass Frame Spacer Tube 2
3 000993 6mm Glass Left Side Clip 1
4 000998 6mm Glass Right Side Clip (Mirror 000993) 1
5 001010 Glass Upper Clip Clamp 1
6 001044 Glass Lower Clip Clamp 1
7 001062 Glass Frame Bracket 1
8 001074 ST2.2x6.5mm CROSS CSK TAP SCREW A2 5

With reference to the assembly instructions for the Glass Frame Arm Assembly (Drawing No. 001083) assemble the arm of the glass frame assembly.
NOTE: 6mm Glass Left Side Clip (3) and 6mm Glass Right Side Clip (4) positions are reversed compared to Glass Frame Arm Assembly. Refer to graphics above for guidance.
Fit two Glass Frame Spacer Tubes (2) and align the pilot holes in the tubes with the holes in the Glass Frame Bracket.
Fix tubes In place using screws (8).
Once completed place to one side.

M3 x 12mm Finger Screw Assembly. Drawing No. 001050

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000652 M3 x 16 SS Pan Head Screw 1
2 000942 M3 Bolt Grip 1
3 001003 M3 Bolt Grip Cap 1

Tap the M3 bolt grip using a M3 tap. If no tap is available drill out the bolt grip using a 3mm drill.
Put a small amount of glue on the treads just below the head of the M3 Screw
Screw into the bolt grip the M3 x 16 screw (1) until the head reaches the base of the bolt grip (2). If a 3mm drill has been used push the screw (1) into the bolt grip (2).
Push the bolt cap (3) into the end of the bolt grip (2), use glue to fix if necessary.
Repeat 5 times to give 6 finger screw assemblies.
Once completed place to one side.

Tablet Clip Assembly Drawing No. 001036

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000653 M3 SS Nut 2
2 001039 Tablet Clamp 1
3 001040 Tablet Clamp Front End Cover 1
4 001041 Tablet Clamp Rear Cover 1
5 001049 M3 Nut Cover 1
6 001050 M3 x 12mm Finger Screw Assembly 1
7 001084 M3 x 30 SS Pan Head Screw 1
8 001085 Compression Spring Hilka 9.5 x 19.1mm 1
9 001111 Tablet Clamp Clip 1

Using a fine file ensure the Tablet Clamp Clip (9) and the Tablet Clamp (2) are a smooth fit without binding. Tap M3 or drill (3mm) the Tablet Clamp Clip (9) and screw or push the M3 x 30 SS Pan Head Screw (7) fully into the Table Clamp Clip (9).
Assemble the clamp using the Tablet Clamp Clip (9) and the Tablet Clamp (2) with the Compression Spring (8) placed over the M3 screw (7), Compress the assembly together and place the M3 nut (1) onto the end of the M3 screw (7). You will need to keep the assembly compressed while you put the nut in place. Only screw the nut onto the very end of the screw (7). Test the assembly to ensure it expands under the force of the spring without binding. If it binds dis-assemble and use a fine file to smooth the components. Once the clamp operates smoothly apply a small amount of glue to the nut (1) to lock it to the screw (7).
Glue the Tablet Clamp Front End Cover (3) and Tablet Clamp Rear Cover (4) in place.
Using a M3 x 12mm Finger Screw Assembly (6) screw into the M3 nut (1)
Once completed place to one side.

Left Tablet Support Assemblies Right Tablet Support Assemblies Left and Right Tablet Support Assemblies Drawing No.001101 / 001100

Left Tablet Support Assembly Drawing N0. 001101
Item Part Description Quantity
1 000653 M3 SS Nut 1
2 001049 M3 Nut Cover 1
3 001050 M3 x 12mm Finger Screw Assembly 1
4 001099 Left Tablet Bracket 1

Right Tablet Support Assembly Drawing N0. 001100
Item Part Description Quantity
1 000653 M3 SS Nut 1
2 001049 M3 Nut Cover 1
3 001050 M3 x 12mm Finger Screw Assembly 1
4 001098 Right Tablet Bracket 1

Insert the M3 nut (1) into the tablet bracket (4). Tis can be assisted by placing the nut onto the very end of the screw of the pre-assembled finger screw assembly and pushing it into the bracket.
Using the pre-assembled finger screw assembly screw into the nut through the bracket as shown. Tighten to finger tight to position M3 nut in correct location. Loosen the finger screw assembly so it is not compressing the bracket but is retained in the nut.
Glue the M3 Nut cover (2) into place. Take care not to apply too much glue so it does not get onto the nut or screw underneath.
Repeat so you have two, a left and right, tablet bracket assemblies.
Once completed place to one side.

Tablet Support Assembly Drawing No. 001097

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000653 M3 SS Nut 1
2 000932 10 x 1mm wall tube end 2
3 001049 M3 Nut Cover 1
4 001050 M3 x 12mm Finger Screw Assembly 1
5 001074 ST2.2x6.5mm CROSS CSK TAP SCREW A2 2
6 001096 Back Tablet Support Tube 1
7 001100 Right Tablet Support Assembly 1
8 001101 Left Tablet Support Assembly 1
9 001107 Tablet Support Bracket 1

Slide tablet support bracket (9) over the back tablet support tube (6) and secure with two screws, as before don’t overtighten. If the support bracket is too tight use a round file to make it a neat fit.
Assemble a pre-assembled finger screw assembly, nut (1) and nut cover (3) into the back tablet support with reference to the left and right tablet support assembly instructions above for detail.
Slide the left and right tablet support assemblies (7 & 8) onto the back tablet support tube (6). Note the diagram above for the correct way round.
Glue 10 x 1mm wall tube ends into the ends of the back tablet support tube (6) .
Once completed place to one side.

Rear Camera Rig Bracket Subassembly Drawing No. 001126

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000083 M3 Plain Washer 3
2 000652 M3 x 16 SS Pan Head Screw 3
3 000653 M3 SS Nut 3
4 001076 M6 MS Plane Washer 1
5 001077 M6 x 40 MS Bolt 1
6 001103 Bracket Back 1
7 001104 Bracket front 1
8 001110 Central Nut Support 3
9 001113 M6 MS Nut 1
10 001114 Camera Rig Bracket Nut Cover 1

Push 3 M3 nuts (3) into the bracket front (7) from the rear of the bracket. Place M3 washers (1) onto the M3 x 16mm screws (2) and screw into the nuts from the front of the bracket to correctly position the nuts. Remove the M3 screws for fitting the central nut supports (8). Glue the central nut supports (8) into place to cover the nuts. Be careful to push the supports fully into the slots in the front bracket. Be careful not to get glue onto the front face of the covers or onto the nuts. Once glue is set reinsert the M3 screws and washers.
Insert the M6 bolt (5) into the front bracket and push to the bottom of the hole. Insert into the bracket back (6). Secure using M6 washer (4) and nut (9). Tighten nut. For extra security the front bracket can also be glued into place.
Cover the M6 nut using the camera rig bracket nut cover (10). If necessary glue into place.
 

Rear Camera Rig Bracket Assembly Drawing No. 001105

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000653 M3 SS Nut 2
2 001017 Clamp Nut Bracket 2
3 001020 Nut Clamp Cap 2
4 001050 M3 x 12mm Finger Screw Assembly 2
5 001126 Rear Camera Rig Bracket Subassembly 1

Using the rear camera rig bracket subassembly (5) glue the clamp nut brackets (2) into place.
Insert a M3 nut (1) into the clamp nut brackets (2).
Glue a nut clamp cap (3) onto the top of the clamp nut brackets (2) being careful not to get glue onto the M3 nuts. Check orientation of the cap before fitting, it will fit both ways but be a better fit one way.
Insert a pre-assembled finger screw assembly into each side of the rear camera rig bracket subassembly (5) as shown.

Base Assembly Drawing No. 001128

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000957 Back Support Tube 1
2 000987 Right Glass frame Assembly Hinge 1
3 000988 Left Glass Frame Assembly Hinge 1
4 001072 10mm Tube Restraint 2
5 001074 ST2.2x6.5mm CROSS CSK TAP SCREW A2 4
6 001105 Rear Camera Rig Bracket Assembly 1

Slide the back support tube (1) onto the rear camera rig bracket assembly (6). Slide a 10mm tube restraint (4) either side and secure using screws (5).
Secure the left and right glass frame assembly hinges (2 & 3) to the ends of the back support frame using screws (5). Pay particular attention to the picture above for orientation and to make sure they are fitted to the right ends.

Base Assembly Drawing No. 001108

Item Part Description Quantity
1 000932 10 x 1mm wall tube end 2
2 001036 Tablet Clip Assembly 1
3 001038 Tablet Support Tube 1
4 001074 ST2.2x6.5mm CROSS CSK TAP SCREW, A2 4
5 001097 Tablet Support Assembly 1
6 001109 Rig Bracket Tube End Cap 2
7 001112 Tablet Support Tube Short 1
8 001128 Base Subassembly 1

Push the tablet support tubes (3 & 7) into the base subassembly and secure in place using screws (4).
Thread the tablet support assembly (8) onto the tablet support arms (3 & 7) and lock in place.
Thread the tablet clip assembly onto the longer tablet support arm (3) and lock in place.
Glue in place the 10 x 1mm wall tube ends (1) into the ends of the tablet support tubes (3 & 7).

PTP2 Blackout Hood Drawing No. 001012 / 001012_PATTERN

The blackout hood is, after the mirror or Glass, the next most important element of the teleprompter. You might have seen designs that don’t have hoods and they will work to a point, but not well. As soon as you get any light from behind or above the camera hitting the mirror or glass you will see a reflection in the camera. This is one component you don’t want to skimp on.
I am a mechanical engineer and not a seamstress and that was clear when I took my designs to my local fabric shop. Anyway after some very funny looks and some explaining they were happy there was enough information there to make the hood. I must admit I was very happy with the results, but I recognise my designs could be optimised / made clearer. If there is anyone who would like to make some recommendations on how to turn this into more of a pattern please let me know.
The material should be a blackout material. Don’t try and use heavy black material, it won’t work. The drawing 001012_Pattern has the cut-out; It’s an A1 drawing so I print it across multiple pages. Make sure you select to print it out actual size without scaling. I have included some dimensions on the drawing so you can check its printed correctly.
The design allows for 25mm of overlap for the hem with a 10mm hem where the hood joins. You will need to put elastic into the hems at the front and back. The best elastic I have found to use was a 2.5mm cord type although I am open to suggestions. Around the front large opening you need a continuous loop. For the elastic I had an un-stretched length of 650mm seemed to work, this will depend on how stretchy the elastic you have is, when its fitted to the teleprompter you need it to be tight enough that the mirror or glass can’t come out. For the other end I used the same elastic 560mm long as it had to exit along the bottom edge. I used a spring cord toggle on the end of this elastic with the ends tied together.
The pattern shows where to put the hook and loop fasteners. Don’t be tempted to use self-adhesive strip as this will come off in use. If sewing the fasteners on does not appeal then a good contact adhesive will work. Don’t forget to glue these on the inside of the hood.

PTP2 Teleprompter Drawing No. 000992

Insert the glass frame assembly (2) into the base assembly (6) as shown in the picture above.
Fix the glass frame arm assembly (5) to the end of the glass frame assembly (2)using 2 screws (4).
Clip the half mirror (1) or glass into the frame and fit the blackout hood (3)
Congratulations you are now the proud owner of a fully assembled PTP2 teleprompter!
Now head over to www.dualpeaks .co.uk for the setup video!

title: Handheld 3-Axis Gimbal For GoPro, Yi, Runcam2 or Rollei410

description.text:
Idea and Sources

I made the crossfire2, a 3d-printed quadcopter, which came with a case for the gopro. First I designed a mount for my actioncam, that I owned at that time, the rollei. Then followed a runcam and at last a xiaomi yi.
I redesigned the gimbal to work on three axis instead of two and all worked well.

Than I had the idea, to make a handheld gimbal from those parts and I remembered the rig by Thumber (that I remixed to use it with a smartphone as well).

Components

All I had to do, was design a simple base plate to fit to the rig. I added a motor mount an a plate to carry the controller. There are no dampening balls as there are no propellers running, that cause vibrations. You can use nylon screws to mount the board. I used a self-adhesive velcro pad instead. So I can remove the board when I need access to any of the connectors.
Underneath the plate there is a slot for a velco strip to attach a battery.

I used a STorm32 controller, three 2208 motors and a 2s-lipo. As I added no joystick so I use a Pan-Hod-Pan mode. See the video to understand how it works.

https://youtu.be/OVhpZQHUhlQ

I add a screenshot of the PID-Settings for the run cam as well. See the Storm32 Wiki on how to set those accordingly to improve the performance of your rig.

Parts

The rig and the baseplate are common for all cameras.
The arms and cases are named in a way, that you will know how to combine them.
You will need some 3mm screws a velcro strip for the battery and maybe a velcro pad to fix the controller as well.

Printing

The gimbal_arm0 needs support and the cases do as well.
The baseplate has to be printed without support standing upright.

You will find the FreeCAD-Files of most of the parts in the remixed sources.

description.text: for you piggy

This is a stylized butterfly design which is good for a pendant, or put together with other butterflies to make a mobile.  
It was an experiment to see if I could achieve a "lacy" look with a Makerbot Replicator 2.  
Update 2014 Mar 12: I added an .obj version

For a more sturdy feel, use:
infill = 0%
number of shells = 2
layer height = 0.2mm (default) For more delicate look, use:
number of shells = 1 You can get very nice bicolor look if you switch the color of the filament partway through when it's printing the outline only. You can also bend it by using a heated glue gun (without the glue) to bend it lengthwise along the thorax. The best size seems to be approx. 4 x 4 cm. But I have also printed it at large as 10 x 10 cm.

title: Children Game [2y+] : My Little Farm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this little game, inspired by a small game called "König Kasimir und seine tiere"

https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/65015/konig-kasimir-und-seine-tiere.

Very simple principle. Roll the dice and choose an animal of the same color, name it and add it to the queue in front of the barn. If there is no animal left of the right color, pass or put one from the queue at the end of the queue. The game end when all the animal are in the queue.
If you roll the multicolor side, you can choose any animal you want.

For the moment, the farmgirl as no other purpose than free play, but I may add some rule later, that the animals must line up before she arrives (from where ? when does she move ?)

Not the most complex game, but my two years and near a half enjoy it very much (and not only in free play).

All the material can be packed in the farm/barn.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4mm

Notes:

No printing difficulties here.
Choose four different color for the four class of animals (see SVG).

The dice is meant to be printed separatly in the different colors then glued together.

I used Inkscape for the vector images which are (mostly) copyleft images from the web. I have modified the feet of the animals so they have flat feet for better stability.

Then I used the "Inkscape to OpenSCAD converter" script to transform the vector images to 2.5D animals. I found that 7.5mm was a good thickness for the animal size.

The farm was made directly in OpenSCAD. You can edit the file so you can change the text written. The OpenSCAD is not much commented but should be not too hard to understand.

If not, don't hesitate to contact me :)

title: Tevo Tarantula simple modular X carriage with layer fan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://youtu.be/uL2P0k8Ls94

-Inspired by other magnetic modular x carriages, I present you this modular X-carriage for Tevo Tarantula 40x20mm rail.
-Simpler build and design, less material to print, less mass and vibrations, less room for errors.
-Extruder is mounted to plate via 6mm magnets.
-Magnets to be mounted and hot glued if needed
-51mm radial fan is mounted to the back via foam tape to eliminate noise and vibration.
-Radial fan's position also balances with the extruder.
-An external x axis limit switch plate is added to the left z axis carriage to activate the limit switch; the limit switch is mounted at the back of the front plate. (Refer to images)
-Belt to be mounted on the top 2 screws (left and right)

Disclaimer: I obtained dimensions from E3D official documentation/ drawings and a little bit of googling for BL touch, therefore dimensions may be inaccurate. I do not earn tips and money for designing these parts and I did waste my very own filaments during the prototyping process. Feel free to leave a note if the parts didn't work out, or better yet offer me the real dimensions!

Printed parts (in red):

  1. Front plate
  2. Back plate
  3. Extruder mount
  4. Fan duct
  5. Limit switch plate
  6. Laser mount
  7. E3D mount
  8. E3D mount flange
  9. BL touch mount * mirror it to mount it on the left side

Additional parts (in purple):

  1. 6mm magnets
  2. Radial fan

Reused parts from printer (in green):

  1. Screws
  2. Left z axis plate
  3. Extruder
  4. 40x20mm rail
  5. Wheels

comments.text: Thanks for the comment! Yes it would be more stable if there were 2 wheels on the upper side, but the tension of the belts keep the 1 wheel configuration as stable as the 2 wheel. The design you referred to is really cool and complete but it has two 20mm rail spaced with like 10mm gap in between. The belt is in that gap. In the stock Tevo Tarantula it uses a 40mm rail instead. Being said, the Black Widow's configuration was 2 wheels on the top 20mm rail, belt in the space between the rails, and 1 wheel at the bottom 20mm rail. That requires some serious mod if you are to go in that direction. My design is more like a slap and go kind of design for the bare stock Tarantula.

print_settings.Notes:: WARNING: I think most FDM print materials are flammable, and probably not designed for insulation, so this shouldn't be considered as some sort of protector for your batteries!

description.text:
Well, after 2 batteries went pole-to-pole and managed to short, causing spectacular amounts of sparking and smoke, I decided to put some covers over the terminals - kind of like shutting the barn door after all the animals leave, but whatever. One terminal turned into slag, but both batteries seem to still work (time will tell).

These fit over my motorcycle-style battery terminals.

I've provided left & right sides with cutouts on opposite sides.

Disclosure: Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the Creailty CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

WARNING: These covers are not intended to insulate or protect. Most plastics are flammable, and mine aren't rated as insulators, so these should'n't be depended upon for anything safety-wise whatsoever. Use at your own risk.

I used simplify 3d to print to my Creality CR-10.

WARNING: I think most FDM print materials are flammable, and probably not designed for insulation, so this shouldn't be considered as some sort of protector for your batteries!

author: Flavz

title: 8mm Slip Ring Mounting Plate for 7.5mm slip ring

description.text:
L3-G0 has a spinny dome connected to the main body power with a slip ring, which lets the wires spin.

But... I have to be able to take off his dome, so there's a plug inside it. I had loose wires with a barrel plug hanging down that kept getting loose. In order to secure things better, I needed to secure the lower end to the top of the slip ring, which is a little cylindrical post with wires coming out the middle.

So this is just a sleeve that presses very tightly onto my post, with a hole in the middle for the wires to escape.

My slip ring's post is ~8mm diameter and 8mm tall

I expect you'll want to mash it up with something needing mounting to the slip ring that's interesting for your purposes.

This model fit very snugly on my slip ring. You may need to resize or build something similar for other slip rings.

description.text:
The parts and assembly are of the Openbuilds Acro Laser System for a CNC controlled laser engraver diode module for the purpose of 3D printing/laser cutting or CNC cutting the panels. It is not complete - it is just the basic frame parts - it is pretty simple to figure out what else you need - e.g. 3x nema 17 motors, gt2 open belt, nuts and bolts, arduino unit with grbl, 12x Vslot wheels, 2x 2020 vslot extrusions for cross brace and 2x 2040 beams for Y-Axis, 1x 2040 for X-axis, laser module, 4x 2020 corner brackets.... etc ...etc....

So i could not find the necessary Solidworks files i needed in order to manipulate the parts to suite my needs, so i translated the parts from Sketchup to STL.

NOTE - these parts are not my own, full credit goes to the OpenBuilds team, i simply converted and cleaned up the file formats and parts as best i could to suit my needs. There may be some dims discrepancy by 0.1/0.2 or a mm here and there for the purpose of material shrinkage during 3D printing.

Check out the Youtube video for assembly instructions, parts and just the overall machine in general.

Enjoy

print_settings.Notes:: Hobby King PLA

description.text:
DAISY is an object for testing and comparing different print cooling solutions, like fan ducts of different shapes, or fans from different manufacturers.

  • It is rotationally symmetrical so that cooling is tested in 360°.
  • The overhangs rapidly increase in steepness from 65° all the way to horizontal. Every layer is more overhang-y than the one before it.
  • The thin tips of the petals are prone to warping and curling without adequate cooling.
  • The front of DAISY is marked for easy orientation and comparison.
  • Prints in around 15 minutes so that you can iterate on settings faster.

Notes:

Obviously, your slicer settings ultimately determine the difficulty of this print. As a rule of thumb, you should print DAISY with the most difficult settings that you think your printer is capable of. I have been using:

  • Hobby King PLA
  • 0.40 mm nozzle and 0.20 mm layer height
  • Base speed 100 mm/s
  • Slow down for layers shorter than 1 second (DAISY has no short layers, though).
  • 2 perimeters
  • 4 top and bottom layers
  • Outline direction inside-out
  • 0 % internal infill
  • Concentric external infill (it is more difficult than rectilinear because only the outer lines anchor to the walls)
A bit shorter version, fits on 180mm Kossel table.
