A Wi-Fi connected laundry alarm for Maytag 2000 series laundry machines. The device senses which front panel LED indicator light is turned on and displays the laundry's status on a local network page you can view in a web browser from a PC, smartphone, tablet, etc.

Updates:

  • 2017 Nov 9
    • Fixed a coding error (funny spelling mistake in the HTML portion of the firmware).

  • 2018 Jan 14
    • Added separate pages for washer and Dryer.
    • The machine cycle is now displayed in the window title or tab.

  • 2018 Jan 15
    • Added simple linked index at address root.

Future Plans:

  • A Huzzah ESP8266 laundry alarm client with OLED display has been prototyped.

Bill of Materials:

  • Adafruit Huzzah esp8266 Wi-Fi breakout board ~ $13 CAD
  • 6x Diodes ~ $6 - $12 CAD for pack of 100
  • 6x 100kΩ resistors ~ $1 for pack of 10
  • 6x Photoresistors ~ $5 for pack of 10
  • 2x strong magnets (12mm diametre, 3 mm tall
  • Perfboard (for building the circuit)
  • ~ 16 Gauge Wire & Shrink Tubing

Tools:

  • 3D Printer
  • Computer with Arduino IDE (instructions for setup are below)
  • USB FTDI Cable (for programming the Wi-Fi breakout board)
  • Soldering Iron and Solder
  • Electronics Side Cutters
  • Sharp Knife
  • Wire Strippers
  • Sand Paper ~ 150 grit
  • Waxed Paper
  • Toothpick

Instructions:

  1. First lets make sure you have a fully working Wi-Fi breakout board. It would be a shame to go to all the trouble of building the laundry alarm only to discover that the board was D.O.A.. Download and install the latest Arduino IDE for your computer's operating system. Next, get the Arduino IDE setup for the Huzza Wi-Fi board by following the Adafruit guide Here.

  2. With the Arduino IDE working, open the source code file downloaded with the 3D printable frame "Laundry_Alarm_Huzzah_ESP8266.ino". You'll need to modify a few lines in that file to get the device connected to your Wi-Fi network. On line 41, you will need to enter your network's SSID between the double quotes. On line 42, enter your networks password between the double quotes. On line 43, give your Wi-Fi board a static ip address within your routers range. Take note that these have comma separated values eg. 192,168,1,100. You do not need to enter your gateway and subnet. If you wish to use your router to assign a static ip, you can comment out line 43 and 161 by typing "//" without the quotes at the beginning of those lines. Now hit the upload button to program the Huzzah Wi-Fi board.

  3. Use an electronics breadboard to build the circuit and make sure everything is working properly before going ahead with the rest of the build. (schematics can be found in the pictures at the top of the page, in the instructions below, and in the file downloads.

  4. 3D print the model and remove any adhesion material with a sharp knife. Sand any surface that will be in contact with your laundry machine and do any regular post processing to clean up the print. Place some wax paper on a flat, magnetically attractive surface. Rough the rear face and sides of the two magnets, mix some epoxy and glue the magnets in the frame. Place the frame magnet side down on the wax paper and place something heavy on top of the frame while the epoxy cures. This will ensure the magnets are flush with the outer surface of the frame, making a strong magnetic bond with your laundry machine while in use.

  5. The microcontroller in the esp8266 Wi-Fi module has only one analogue input, so to take analogue readings from multiple sensors, a small circuit will have to be built which uses 6 digital pins to power each of the sensors. One by one, each sensor will be given power and an analogue reading will be taken. The highest value from those readings will be from the led on the laundry machine that was turned on, giving us the cycle in which the machine is currently engaged.

    For testing, I used a wire wrap tool and wire jumpers to assemble the circuit leaving an ugly mess of wires. I originally used 10kΩ resistors which were too low a value for sensing the dim LEDs on my laundry machines. Switching to 100kΩ resistors resulted in much more stable light readings. For the final build I put together a compact circuit board that fits under the Huzzah Wi-Fi board, serving the secondary purpose of securing the Wi-Fi board to the frame.
    Start by drawing an outline of the circuit board, and use a sharp knife to cut a 3 x 6 solder pad grid as shown below.

  6. Bend and trim the leads of the six diodes and and six resistors to for 3/10 inch spacing and lay out the components as below. Solder the components in place.

  7. Remove two to three millimetres of insulation from the end of six wires and splay the strands of each wire as pictured below. Tin the wires and solder each wire connecting each diode in line with its adjacent resistor.If you haven't already, make a solder bridge to attach the cathode ends of the diodes to the pad where the analogue pin of the Wi-Fi board will go, and another bridge from the resistors to the pad that the Ground pin will go.

  8. Trim the board to size.

  9. Set the circuit board aside for now. Insert the six photoresistors in the frame recesses. make sure they sit flush with the rear wall of the recesses.Mix enough two part epoxy to glue the photoresistors in place. Using a toothpick, pick up some epoxy and place a drop on either side of the photoresistors being careful not to get any on the face of the sensor.

  10. Once the epoxy is cured, trim the photoresistor leads to about three millimetres length. Take the Huzzah Wi-Fi board and place it in the top of the frame.Take the circuit board you built earlier and fit it to the bottom of the Wi-Fi board sandwiching the frame between them, making sure the analogue and ground pins are in the right holes of the circuit board.

  11. Solder both Ground Pins, pins 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 4, and TX to secure the circuit board to the Wi-Fi board. Trim a short amount of insulation off of six wires and tin their ends. There is very little room to solder wires to the rear pins. Place the frame circuit board side up with the magnets pointing toward you. If you solder with your right hand, solder a wire to pin 13 first, then 12, 14, and finally 16. If you are left handed, solder the wires in the reverse order. solder the last two wires to pins 15 and 4. Now is a good time to place shrink tubing over all of the wires connected to the circuit board.

  12. All that's left now is to trim the wires to length slip some shrink tubing on each wire and solder them to the photoresistors. Start with the wire from pin 16 and pair it with any wire between the diodes and resistors on the circuit board. It doesn't matter which one you chose as they all take the same electrical path to the ground and analogue pins. In the photo below, the photoresistor leads from left to right go to pins 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, and 4; 16 being directly below the loop that the wires go though. Bend the photoresistor leads for pin 16 toward the loop, trim the two wires to length, slip some heat shrink tubing over them and solder the wires to the leads, shrink the tubing, then do the same for photo resistors 4 and 15, then 14, 13, and finally 12.

  13. I'ts time to test it out. The board should magnetically connect to the metal surface at the top of the laundry machine aligning the six sensors with the laundry cycle LEDs on the front display. You can power the board with an FTDI cable and a USB power adapter, or you can cut the end off a spare USB cable and solder some female jumper wires to the ground and 5v wires of the USB cable. Connect the jumper wires to the ground and +5v pins of the FTDI header on the Huzza Wi-Fi board, and the other end of the USB cable to a power adapter and start a load of laundry.

  14. Open a web browser on a computer connected to your home network. In the address field, type in the ip address of the Wi-Fi board and the machine you want to monitor separated by a forward slash (ex 192.168.1.100/washer or 192.168.1.100/dryer) to view the laundry machines current status. The page will automatically refresh every 60 sec to let you know what the machine is doing. Now you'll be alerted with a red/orange/blue flashing page the minute your laundry is done.

  15. If you type "/rawWasher" or "/rawDryer" without the quotes after the ip address (ex 192.168.1.100/rawWasher), you will be shown the the current laundry cycle and the latest readings of all of the sensors refreshed every 5 seconds.

comments.text:
Very nice idea and description of the solution. What a pity that it doesn't work for our laundry machine. Ours has a display which is not so easy to decode and no single indicators.
But anyway, I like it!
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text:
Thanks TuxMan,
This is something I've wanted to build for a long time. Another project that I've been working on recently led me to discover the esp8266 wifi module and the Huzzah breakout that Adafruit designed for it. It's an impressive little Wi-Fi module that's given me a few ideas. And it's so inexpensive, bought a few of them for other projects.
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text:
You probably don't know about the WAF (Wife's Acceptance Factor). As soon as I do any manipulation in the machine I'm responsible for everything that happens with it. Soon it would be louder, jumping higher, washing longer, .... as before, even if it has absolutely nothing to do with the manipulation ;-)
Believe me, I have nearly 50 years experience with things like this ;-)
By the way, I already have some experience with the esp8266 and alikes. One tells me if the garage door is open and another one will tell me in the near future if there is mail in the mailbox. And I was already thinking about a reminder for the laundry machine but left it for the reasons I described.
comments.author: ReallyBigTeeth

comments.text: We'll, that's half the adventure right there!  Too funny.  It's better to have something easily removable.
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text: I see you also have a Felix 3.  I was just thinking about getting the Tec 4 upgrade myself.  The bed leveling feature looks nice, but it's a lot of money.  It would have been nice to see a Wi-Fi feature included in upgrade.  I was going over the firmware two nights ago trying to figure out if I could connect a Huzzah board to the printer without changing too much of the firmware.  There's a lot of code in there.  You'll have to let me know what you think about the upgrade.
comments.author: TuxMan

comments.text:
I originally also had the Felix 3 but got it as a Demo machine including the upgrade kit to 3.1 which I had meanwhile installed. Now I bought the upgrade to TEC4 which is really expensive compared to some other 3D printer. You can get a Prusa DIY kit for the same price, at least for my dual head version. On the other hand you get all the expensive parts new. I was long thinking about, but came to the conclusion to buy it. If it works it will be a high quality machine. It was already in my version and with the upgrade it will probably still be better. At the moment I am removing all the wrappings from the wires und the parts that will be replaced. I am not working "fulltime" on it, so it will last a bit longer until it will be finished.
One of the most important reasons for my decision to buy a Felix was the "open source" HW and the upgradeability but when it comes to the prices it is always expensive. Even if the parts are not, the shipping cost from the NL wit UPS are very high. I'm not sure now, but I guess at least the nozzles in the new version are more common than the ones in 3.0 and 3.1 so that other offerings on the market (China) could be used.
If you are interested I will keep you informed. Maybe we should than exchange email addresses.
I have added a picture of the actual state. I don't know if you can see it, it's the first time I try to attach a file to a comment in here.
Because of your comment with the WiFi connection - have you thought about using an octopi? This will be one of my next projects within the "hundreds" of my pipeline ;-)

comments.author: ister

comments.text:
Let me know if I forgot to upload any files.
I used a Maglev 220V(EU) fan to reduce the noise and temperature. It is still a bit noisy. I live in Greece (warm country) keep the NAS in a bookshelf and had no melting part issues.
I tried to investigate why the disk failed in the mentioned configuration and recovery (see previous message), I identified which disk failed, removed it, inserted it in a PC and it worked fine. Tried to add it again on the same NAS slot and no success. Restarted (with shutdown -r now) the NAS and still it did not work. Then I shutdown, unplugged the NAS from power socket and restarted. It did work. The conclusion is that it was a failure of the USB2SATA interface and it seems that 12V still keeps its electronics running. You might want to experiment with different USB2SATA interface but you will have to re-design the USB2SATA mount part.
Also if I remember correctly I had to install the odroid latest kernel (4.x.y if I remember correctly, I used a beta distribution from the official site) but I cannot remember the reason.

title: Screwdriver holder for IKEA SKÅDIS pegboard, 6 smaller screwdrivers

description.text:
I really love my Ikea Skadis Pegboard, and i love the Screwdriver Holder from @GoToMake (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2553466) so i enhanced his design to fit my needs.

I have some smaller Screwdrivers laying around here (from https://www.real.de/product/308030226/ ) so i made a version with 6 holes and 11mm with. It is not perfect as it could use some more spacing between the screwdrivers. Maybe i will add a more-space version later.

As their handles are smaller than the metal part i made a complete cut to slide them in. My files are around 3mm in diameter so i make it 3.3mm wide.
Also i made 7 slots, although i have only 6 files. It was pretty late...

description.text:
One of the first things many people print when they get a 3D-Printer is a filament spool holder. There are a lot of models out there on Thingiverse, which mostly are designed to stand on your desk or to be mounted on your printer. But I couldn't find a good one to be mounted directly on a wall, so I decided to design one myself.

The bottom part of the holder has three holes which can be used to fix the holder in place.
The lid consists of three hooks, which snap directly into place, this way the spool holder can easily be closed. To open it again, just give it a little twist. The minimal inner diameter of the spool has to be >50mm, but you can download and edit the Fusion360 file anytime if your spool has some exotic dimensions.

Notes:

The lid has to be printed with supports, on the bottom part this is optional

description.text:
I don't remember why I designed this spool holder while there are many available, probably couldn't find a customizable one and some dimensions didn't match.

At any rate, recently I had to reprint it and after digging out the scad file I thought I'd publish it, so here it goes. It takes four bearings, four M3 screws and four nuts to make one. You can go customize it beyond using M3 screws, but for that you'll need to go into openscad, not just customizer.

The source is also available in the repository at https://gitlab.com/parts/spoolery

comments.text: Depends on which one you printed. There are two prerendered STLs for 623 (10x4) and 624 (13x5), I suspect you printed the one for 623 (as it's the smaller one). You can also customize for your bearings size, just open it in customizer and specify the dimensions.

I decided to modify original blower duct of whpthomas in order to gain access to the screws under the extruder carriage.
This version has a pivot between the support and the duct, so you will get off the carriage without unscrewing the duct, but simply moving it.
As pin i used a 3x20 screw because only the last piece of duct is threaded, the remaining is a bit larger to avoid the pin unscrews by rotation.

title: OnePlus 3 / 3T Wallet Case - Customizable
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Optimized for Semiflex/Cheetah. Ninjaflex will probaly work, too.
Some softer types of pla may work, but the hinge can break eventually.

Customizable types: Wallet Case, Flip Case, Bumper
Customizable text: You can add your own name or signature in customizer, by default its "OnePlus"

Default settings:
Wallet Case with 3 credit card pockets, one extra pocket and an integrated stand.

Red case=Semiflex, transparent=Taulman PCTPE

We all suffer from bad bed adhision from time to time, why not use it to our advantage?
When adding a small air gap between layers they still adhere during printing but can be seperated to form pockets :-)
I used Simplify3D, not tested with other slicers.

If you have problems separating the layers add a small piece of tape at the air gaps during printing. Usually its enough to have a 3mm wide opening to insert a screw driver and succesively open the pocket. I used a piece of kapton tape for the stand only, you can see it on the picture (yellow tape). If you use too much tape the layers may separate during printing which can cause deformation or a failed print.

You should use a flexible material for flip and wallet case styles, as the hinge can break after some time with harder materials.
Optimized for Semiflex/Cheetah, but sucessfully used Taulman PCTPE (which is a combination of Nylon and TPE=Ninjaflex), too.

For Taulman PCTPE use following settings:
layerHeight: 0.1
standZLayer: 5
caseSideThickness: 1.9
caseTopBottomThickness: 1.9
phoneDimensionAdditionalX: 0.1
phoneDimensionAdditionalY: 0.1
phoneDimensionAdditionalZ: 0.1

description.text:
This is a case for the UDOO X86 Single Board Computer, designed in Onshape.

I've added some holes and plugs for SMA Female RF connectors for those with the Ultra edition of the card, or have just added a wifi mini pcie card - you'll want to use SMA female jacks with mcx flyleads, and these should mount into the hole in the case and be secured with the nut on the outside of the case.

I've designed it around this type of lead: https://www.digikey.co.uk/product-detail/en/amphenol-rf-division/245130-01-24.00/ACX2530-ND/5030811

I've printed a version of this off now, and it fits very well, support material was a bit hard to remove around the rear ports due to the wall thickness, so I've thickened that area a little more to hopefully avoid cracking the plastic like I just did...

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

You'll need to flip the top over 180 degrees before printing, The vent-holes might be a bit small, so getting the support material out might be a pain.

Case screws are 4 x M3 Cap Head Hex screws, with the nuts mounted into the sections in the base.

The board should snap into the mounting points on the base, then secured with M2.5 x 5mm machine screws. (These screw into PLA quite nicely I've found.)
Designed in Onshape, the source files are available here if anyone wants to play with them.

author: danielsikora

description.text:
I made this stand for my pioneer CDJ 800s. I use 800s professionally as they are very easy to repair and parts are cheap while keeping vinyl emulation mode - ideal for a timecode system.
I decided that as I have four I would mount two of them with my home setup.
As I am a repairer of this equipment I had no problem drilling four holes through the bottom of the back plate, I know it wont effect anything inside. Please only do this if you know what you are doing, Im not going to pay to replace your nexus 2000s after you stick a drill through the laser! anyway disclaimer over.

This design requires a few M4 bolts, poundland sell lovely little packs which i used for this.
I printed this at 20% fill and i think about a 0.15 layer height. If the pivot gets a little loose you can use some thread lock on the bolt, a drop of super glue or a wedge - which is so easy to get in there based on the pivot design. If it did get loose then dont panic, it can only move within a range anyway.

The design is strong.... SERIOUSLY strong. I put the bottom section between two bricks and was able to stand on it!

Happy printing

comments.text:
Someone has just made a super remix for the CDJ 1000 MK3,
I also have a updated version for the cdj 400 series that i will upload (bolts straight onto the pivot and makes the decks removable)
Thank you for contributing to my project :D

title: Angle meter for wrist, knee, ankle

description.text:
After suffering a scaphoid fracture and doing ergo training I found it useful to get the angle measured that I can move my wrist joint - in both ways. So I designed a big enough meter that allows to measure that with one hand.

The pointer is divided, having a 90° grid, and can be changed in 2 seconds.See pics.

Update: I rounded the pointers at their base, since I realized you have to turn it for the other side of the body...

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed with PLA since warpage would be strong for ABS.

Turn B-Pointer upside down for printing.

Paint the protuberant digits carefully using a waterproof pen, also mark the degree marks with a fine one.

Drill the hole for the screw in the pointers smooth (NOT in the baseplate).
Use a M4 x 10/16/20 mm screw. It it does not stick in the baseplate (turn it in with the screwdriver), use few CA-glue - it's fine it it does not move in the baseplate.

Test the 90°-grid between the pointers and flatten where necessary with a nailfile, than add the pointers to the baseplate, top with a washer and a M4-wingnut.

title: WoodenBrainMaster (cnc)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's a classic game invented in the 70th, that goes by different names like Mastermind or Superhirn. I played it with my 9 year old daughter and we had tons of fun, so I decided to recreate the board from solid wood.

I used beautiful 20 mm wood from the checker tree, and milled the parts on my desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft. To get nice carving I took a downcut end mill. This ensures a good edge quality. The holes and the rest was done with a long 3 mm endmill specially intended for wood. The cover is secured by 3 mm neodyn magnets.

Making my own playing pieces was not necessary as I used the ones supplied with my original game.

Be aware that the stl-files are not verified to be useful on an fdm-printer.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

print_settings.Notes:: The top part of the laser module must be printed upside down and is the only one that requires supports, especially the front part of the module. All the other supports (inside holes and letters, air vents) are unwanted products of the support algorithms. Play with the support settings on your software until most of the unwanted supports are not generated (you could for example let the first N layers have forced support). If your software enables creating supports manually, then you are halfway there

description.text:
This is a demonstration geometrical optics set created by me and my colleague Matej Ryston. It is intended for teachers as a cheaper alternative to commercialy available products. Set requires lot of assembly and other components, but finished result is very easy to use and quite usable. All the instructions are in pdf file.

All is magneticaly held to black or white boards. Laser module is powered by Li-Ion batery, charged by micro-USB and as you can see produces quite visible laser line, simulating propagation of a light ray.

Note: (6.11.2017) - Uploaded working model of Laser Rider.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,3 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

We cannot give you precise instructions for printing as too many settings are dependent on your exact type of 3D-printer and software. Following tips are more based on our general experience, rather than precise instructions. Please take them with a grain of salt and adjust them according to your own experience and equipment.
Material:

The choice of material is more or less up to you, based on your experience. We chose PLA and the print was without problems. Furthermore, PLA is a common and cheap material that is supported by (most likely) 100% of common 3D-printers. The second most common filament, ABS, is not recommended unless your printer is inside a controlled environment that supresses draft and sudden changes in temperature. Otherwise the material might bend, deform or split between the layers, because most of the printed parts are of a comparable size with the printing area of most printers, which makes using ABS more difficult.
Details:

We printed all the parts using a layer height of 0.3 mm. Higher precision for smooth finish is not necessary. If you are using printer settings not based on exact numbers, the appropriate setting should be something like normal, prototype or fast.
Brimm

Brimm around the printed parts is supposed to secure higher stability of less stable components. Our set doesn't contain any, so according to our experience, brimm is not necessary.
Orientation and supports:

The orientation of individual components is in most cases pretty obvious. The print is made in the same orientation as the components will be oriented on the board. Although some components have holes for magnets, supports are not necessary. The only exception is the lid of the laser module.

With the larger components, such as mirrors, we recommend orienting them diagonally, so that they fit on the printing bed more easily.

The bottom part of the laser module is also printable without supports. The only place when they are needed is the battery holder; however, its supports are already part of the model. Any other supports are unnecessary.

When printing the inner parts of the laser module, it is necessary to turn the cylindrical lens holder upside down. In this orientation it should get printed without any supports. With the "cradle" and the "riders", it turns out the keeping the right orientation when printing is important. One might want to print the cradle sideways but that leads to closing of the nail holes. The nail should slide through the cradle freely and be stuck in the riders firmly (some degree of force is required). If your printer prints the holes too tight, it is possible to widen them with a heated nail. If the holes are too wide, some glue at the end of the nail might help.

The top part of the laser module must be printed upside down and is the only one that requires supports, especially the front part of the module. All the other supports (inside holes and letters, air vents) are unwanted products of the support algorithms. Play with the support settings on your software until most of the unwanted supports are not generated (you could for example let the first N layers have forced support). If your software enables creating supports manually, then you are halfway there

Postprinting process varies wildly depending on the piece you are making. Some parts require only mild filing of edges, some require molding and casting and some require assembly of electronic board.

It all depends on you what modules you want and can make.

This is a set designed for teachers use only (danger of eye damage). It is a difficult to make but easy to use demonstration set for teaching geometrical optics. If instructions are followed then the resulting set is a very effective and cheap replacement for the commercially availible products.
  • Set is held magneticaly on the board
  • Laser module is battery powered and recharged via micro-USB
  • Light ray is represented with a laser stripe making the ray visible along its path
  • Set is modular. Meaning the user can make just a part of it and expand on it later
    • Our intention was to make a set for teaching following topics:
  • Light reflection
  • Planar, concave and convex mirrors
  • Light refraction
  • Lenses and effect of optical power
  • Light crossing plane parallel layer
  • Total internal reflection
  • Simulation of optical fiber

• Print and assemble the set
  • Introduce the idea of light ray and its propagation through space
  • Demonstrate law of reflection using planar mirror
  • Show how reflection happenes on cylindrical mirrors and explain their apllications
  • Show light refraction on a single layer interface (use parallel plane module)
  • Show propagation thgrough parallel plane module
  • Show propagation through lenses of different optical powers
  • Explain their uses for eye correction
  • Show total internal reflection on planar module
  • Show the function of a optical fiber using module from flexable resin

Short-list This list is here just to give you a general idea of what you will need. For full list with specifics see pdf instructions. 2 compound transparent resin
neodymium magnets (lots)
reflective foil
Strong laser diode (25-50mW)
Li-ion bateries
additional electronics for the driver circuit
• Optics
2-3  45minute lessons

title: Pegaso 1080 for Mr.Crankyface's Chassis (Cab)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This body is specially designed for Mr.CrankyFace chassis. You can find al the mechanical parts in the following links:

Frame: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1695694
Rear Axle: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1676173
Front Axle: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1651135
Gearbox: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1704988
Central Gearbox: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1680949

I also designed these shock aboserbers specially for this truck. I've tested them and they work pretty good.

Shock absorbers: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2252957

When I designed this body some time ago, I wanted to use as less PLA as possible. That is why I just designed the "skin" of the body and then I used 5mm plywood in order to make the body stronger. So the entire design is prepared to use 5mm plywood as you can see in the photos. You will have to glue all the parts and I highly recommend using mounting putty because it makes easier to assemble

The cab is fixed to the frame with the "chassis joints" and 4 M3x20mm screws.

You will also need to make one hole in each "wing" part in order to screw the chassis joints. (Design mistake that I have to solve)

Feel free to remix the cab in order to make it 100% printable or whatever you want.

Here you will only find the cab files. In order to build the entire Pegaso 1080 you will also need this other parts:

Rear Box: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2638780
Wheels: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2648302
Accessories: (In progress)

UPDATE 27/11/2017

Error: Wrong scale in "Windscreen_joint_left"

UPDATE 28/11/2017

Error: "Left_Side_Down.gcode" should be "Left_Side_Down.stl"

Geeetech I3 Pro b

0.2

50

GX counter for Pokemon TCG.

I wanted a more familiar GX counter look than what I found available for personal printing. The measurements are nowhere near exact, in either angle or length, but they are "within the ballpark". Used a cheap plastic ruler, the cardboard cutout GX counter, and traced a PNG image with the "GX" font.

It's my first 3d model ever, the orientation is wrong, and there is some strange business when put into a slicer with the bottom pokeball logo appearing inside the counter as well as on the outside. I may fix this once I get a better understanding...or I might forget about it.

A device designed to allow individuals with cerebral palsy of the hand to use their forearm movement to operate a standard rowing machine.

Devices like this provide low-cost methods for individuals to use gym equipment with minimal preparation.

Please reach out to us with any questions at [email protected] and check out our website (eNableLowell.com) and see our stories and help us create more devices!

description.text:
Hello everybody!

We've been having technical problems with our printer so we haven't been able to print anything! That's why we only upload example photos of our new creations, but if you want you can be our cover photo! You just have to upload your make and we'll put it!!!

We will try to keep on uploading amazing things as long as we can! We hope you understand <3

By now, you can follow us and visit our page to stay tuned and don't miss a thing!! Check our page for more bookmarks and cute supplies ideas and feel free to suggest us new designs on comments!!

Hola a todos!

Hemos estado teniendo algunos problemas técnicos con nuestra impresora, es por eso que sólo hemos podido subir las fotos de prueba. Pero si quieres que tu make aparezca en este post no tienes más que subirlo a esta página y nos encargaremos de ponerlo de portada!

Intentaremos subir cosas geniales en la medida en que nos sea posible, esperamos que lo entiendas <3

Mientras tanto puedes visitar nuestra página para ver más marcapáginas y cosas súper monas!
Déjanos un comentario con tus ideas y nosotros las haremos!

remixed_from.title: Nintendo Switch Cartridges and Micro SD holder

description.text:
Credits to jcarolinares for the idea and Kickass3DPrints for the one print box.

I like the question mark block but i found it more fun to store Switch games in a Switch block :)

The sources are on the side, assembly is fairly easy, just glue the white parts.

You'll need to print:
1 x box
1 x lid
4 x !
16 x screws (4.5mm)

Mine is only printed in 0.2 infill 17% with my dagoma neva. It's my first design (outside the screws i've made everything from scratch) and i'm new to 3D printing, i'm open to suggestions. thanks :)

Edit 1 : Updated the photos with another print in 0.15, they are much nicer :)

description.text:
Designed from ground up as an toy gun prop. Entirely my own design, no references or design from any movie nor other source. Used this design to learn design process from paper+pencil plan, to digital and print.

Frame split to 4 parts due limited size of the print bed on my CoLiDo 3D DIY.

NOTE: Print nozzle with orange (or paint it) to comply legality issues on some countries.
NOTE: NON-FUNCTIONING REPLICA/Prop, does not violate TOS.

Software used:
Inkscape to do SVG from drawing.
Autodesk Fusion 360 to do 3D version.
Sliced with Cura and printed with CoLiDo 3D DIY.

Printer:

CoLiDo 3D DIY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Original design made to paper by pencil drawing. Photographed paper version with measurement visible. Used picture on Inkscape to trace out 2D to vectors. Imported SVG to Fusion 360 where final 3D design was made.

Original design Inkscape version of the design. Fusion 360 design.

comments.text: I printed this for my LCD module, but the thru holes on the PCB did not lineup with the holes on the front panel. I was able to make it fit by filing out the thru holes on the front panel with a round needle file. Then I used nylon stand offs on the pcb to allow for some flexibility. Fastened nylon stand offs to front panel using M3x8 screws. Overall though, this is a great model and I like the way it looks on the X5S.

corps principal adapté pour 3 paliers IGUS RJ4JP-01-08 , avec fentes pour compenser les jeux d'impressions, faciliter le montage, et bridage par vis + écrous (3x écrous M3 + 2x vis M3x10 + 1x vis M3x12)
